data.title: Which characters did you think the MCU turn into a joke?
data.meta_description: So in the MCU, it may just be me but I've noticed some characters started to feel like they were more there for comedy and for being a joke or watering down...
data.text:
PhoenixAKG

Aug 14, 2019

8,317

Aug 8, 2024

#1

So in the MCU, it may just be me but I've noticed some characters started to feel like they were more there for comedy and for being a joke or watering down elements of their comic counterparts which made them more tragic/layered.

For me I think Hulk fits this bill. Like a lot of his issues from the comics (such as his issues with his father) aren't really mentione or dwelled upon that much and it feels like he's been reduced to "funny smash man"

mrbogus

Jul 14, 2019

2,611

Aug 8, 2024

#2

Never cared for the origin story of hard boiled Avengers leader Nick Fury's injured eye to actually end up being some silly alien cat scratch that he seemed to be quite okay with when it happened.

Aug 8, 2024

#3

None, they are comic book characters made to entertain. Made to joke about.

808s & Villainy

Oct 27, 2017

43,881

Aug 8, 2024

#4

i honestly don't even know if Thor is played seriously in the comics. The only Thor comic I read was the one with Gor, meanwhile in pretty much every MCU movie he's just a himbo

Durden

Oct 25, 2017

12,789

Aug 8, 2024

#5

Never cared for the origin story of hard boiled Avengers leader Nick Fury's injured eye to actually end up being some silly alien cat scratch that he seemed to be quite okay with when it happened.

But it's funny, you fucking asshole!

/s. This was seriously a turning point for me with the MCU. A point where they clearly started prioritizing "the audience will just be laugh and not care, and treat everything like our Stark will" over "we should take advantage of what we can do with these characters, especially within this comic book setting".

They gave up on storytelling.

Last edited: Aug 8, 2024

Huskman

Jan 21, 2019

572

Aug 8, 2024

#6

Walton Goggins as an actor seemed to be utilized as a joke where from my limited knowledge of Marvel comics his character is actually quite a threat.

Ronan the accuser comes to mind. He is an actual character in the comics instead of just being a zealot. Being portrayed by Lee Pace just felt more wasteful.

#15

None of them. Especially not Hulk, and I will always consider that complaint ridiculous.

There have been wasted characters, though. More could have been done with Ultron, for sure. And Gorr in Love & Thunder is such a gigantic double waste of both Marvel's best new villain so far this century and one of the best actors in the business today that it should have resulted in a criminal charge.

Oct 26, 2017

Friday at 12:28 AM

#23

i honestly don't even know if Thor is played seriously in the comics. The only Thor comic I read was the one with Gor, meanwhile in pretty much every MCU movie he's just a himbo

This was a big one for me. I wasn't the biggest Thornfan in the comics but I did appreciate the operatic air and mythic flair to the series. They kind of captured that in the first Tjor somewhat at the beginning so i was willing to waitnandnsee. But when he showed up in Avengersn I finally accepted that everyone would just be wise cracking all the time.

It's such a huge miss. Every character should be their own style and themes, to offer the audiences diversity. In stead its justnvarious flavors of action comedy with forced cameos.

Watership

Oct 27, 2017

3,296

Friday at 12:32 AM

#24

Never cared for the origin story of hard boiled Avengers leader Nick Fury's injured eye to actually end up being some silly alien cat scratch that he seemed to be quite okay with when it happened.

Nick Fury comics all the way back to the 60s was full of him using his mystery and myth to his advantage, even when it wasn't true. He kept things so close to the vest and encouraged the legend. Goose taking his vision totally fits that. And flerkins are superb dangerous to boot.

Jotakori

Teyvat Traveler

Oct 25, 2017

3,224

Friday at 12:46 AM

#25

I don't read the comics so this is strictly just based on what's in the MCU itself, but Thor is the worst offender for me. He actually had such wonderful character development up through IW, but then they just kinda shat on it in Endgame, and then they really shat on it in L&T. :/

GoodGrief

Jan 24, 2024

1,515

Friday at 1:00 AM

#26

Shuri, Nick Fury, the Skrulls/Super-Skrull, the Kree, Taskmaster, the Eternals, Namor, Kang, Kamala, Peggy Carter, Dr. Doom... they tried their damnedest with Kingpin, but D'Onofrio's performance always pulled through.

Love and Thunder poisoned the entire Thor cast for me. I just don't wanna see them anymore.

I am nervous that Wiccan is next. They really need to get my boy right.

Friday at 1:13 AM

#27

I don't read the comics but I liked Taskmaster from MvC3, the Insomniac Spider-Man game, and stuff I read on the wiki. Seemed like a cool but also funny character! The MCu version is just… some mute human-experiment girl? I know they're bringing her back for Thunderbolts but I don't see how they can turn the character around.

Also like all of the Thor cast and most of the villains-of-the-week, from what I can tell.

Durden

Oct 25, 2017

12,789

Friday at 1:15 AM

#28

Nick Fury comics all the way back to the 60s was full of him using his mystery and myth to his advantage, even when it wasn't true. He kept things so close to the vest and encouraged the legend. Goose taking his vision totally fits that. And flerkins are superb dangerous to boot.

Completely argue against this. While not disagreeing with you on your core point, maybe the better option is just don't show it at all? And be faithful to the material that made him "mystical" in the first place?

You want to add to the mystery and the legend, maybe write some cool shit to have him talk about vaguely sometimes. Why do you think the Joker in TDK is still so beloved? None of use needed to know why he got his eyepatch in the MCU. They used a prominent part of his character as some cheap-ass way to "connect" these movies and in the process get a quirky giggle, and we all know it. It just demeans him in the process.

This has been the underlying issue with the MCU for quite some time now, simply taking characters for granted.

Chumunga64

Jun 22, 2018

15,111

Friday at 1:15 AM

#29

I don't read the comics but I liked Taskmaster from MvC3, the Insomniac Spider-Man game, and stuff I read on the wiki. Seemed like a cool but also funny character! The MCu version is just… some mute human-experiment girl? I know they're bringing her back for Thunderbolts but I don't see how they can turn the character around.

Also like all of the Thor cast and most of the villains-of-the-week, from what I can tell.

Taskmaster is the opposite problem- the MCU version is devoid of any charm and levity of the original

#30

I mean I'm a huge fan of the MCU but honestly.... most of them?

Hawkeye

Hulk

Thor

the list goes on.

Nacho

Oct 25, 2017

8,407

NYC

Friday at 1:19 AM

#31

I'd say most of the villains especially pre phase 3 (tho many phase 3 and after as well, tho I'll say for all the modern MCU faults, they've on average gotten better with the villains being interesting if not still disposable).

Never cared for the origin story of hard boiled Avengers leader Nick Fury's injured eye to actually end up being some silly alien cat scratch that he seemed to be quite okay with when it happened.

This one doesnt bother me so much just because Sam Jackson sold it. Secret Invasion tho stretch that man's capabilities beyond the possible tho and turned him into a complete idiot and an unjustifiable asshole too.

Friday at 1:19 AM

#32

Thor? It's been awhile since I've watched the movies, but just about everyone he's loved has died or he thinks is dead and they turned him into a big joke. I like comedy, but I think this is going too far.

Friday at 1:51 AM

#33

thor works better in comedy, 2 was the last "serious" movie and it's a tired punchline on here. hemsworth is fun, love & thunder was cheap/lazy compared to part 3 but it gets way overblown on here

and hawkeye could've been better, but there's only so much to work with there that's gonna transfer over

for me, taskmaster was such a shame, he's such a cool character in the books at times. i kinda think the arc "unthinkable" could've been interesting, but i don't know if others liked that one as much as i did at the time

so many villains/heels were totally disposable, i guess ronan was an early one. it's kinda weird seeing namor here, i thought his take in panther was more nuanced than MCU usually gets, wish we'd have had more of him

ultron was a half-baked whedon effort, started out interesting and quickly fell apart. kang was actually pretty cool in loki, and i think he could've been made threatening again even after being kinda silly in ant man if his arc had played out, but it is what it is

swear to god if they get DOOM wrong a third time i'll flip tables

2,958

Friday at 1:52 AM

#34

i honestly don't even know if Thor is played seriously in the comics. The only Thor comic I read was the one with Gor, meanwhile in pretty much every MCU movie he's just a himbo

My coworker once called MCU Thor a 90's Surfer dude and Its the best description of Thor I've ever heard

Hulk needs his own movie to flesh out his character, and then he needs to get angry.

#43

Kang. No, you don't get to be treated as the next Thanos-level threat if your big screen debut has you jobbing to Ant-Man, the Wasp, and an army of giant ants.

Him too. Would've still been getting his ass whooped by Thor and Loki's mom if he didn't have his magic roid goon bail him out.

Never cared for the origin story of hard boiled Avengers leader Nick Fury's injured eye to actually end up being some silly alien cat scratch that he seemed to be quite okay with when it happened.

I rather liked the truth of how it happened vs. whatever gritty explanation seemed more likely to be the reason why.

Back to Kang, you are not a Thanos level threat if you job to Ant-Man of all people.

I always hated MCU's Ultron. I can only hope that one day they might be able to salvage him and make some Guardians/other cosmic movie adapting Annihilation Conquest and have Ultron actually be a terrifying, calculating threat.

#46

A personal one for me is the treatment of Erik Selvig in Thor The Dark World which honestly just felt like mocking mental health issues for cheap ableist jokes. While they course corrected with that in Age of Ultron, the bit in Dark World about Stone Henge just makes me cringe and a sad reminder of how most people think of mental health.

"This guy are sick" and Corrupted by Vengeance

Adam Warlock, but I admit that it and Gunn's entire tone really works for me anyway. I still stand by the reaction that the full reveal of Rocket's arc in Guardians 3 with all of the comedy still felt like a huge and earned emotional journey of grief and anger that had way more depth than most of MCU despite the antics.
